questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding Weber syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Lesion is in the oculomotor nerve fascicles and corticospinal fibers

options.label: B
options.text: Hemiplegia is present on the opposite side of the lesion

options.label: C
options.text: There is a lateral squint on the same side of the lesion

questions.explanation:
Topic

Details

Anatomy involved

Midbrain ventral region (cerebral peduncle) affecting corticospinal tract and oculomotor nerve fascicles

Lesion location

Basis pedunculi of the midbrain

Clinical features

Ipsilateral oculomotor palsy (ptosis, pupil dilation, lateral deviation of eye) and contralateral hemiplegia

Pathophysiology

Damage to corticospinal tract causes contralateral hemiplegia; damage to oculomotor nerve fascicles causes ipsilateral third nerve palsy

Signs

Contralateral hemiplegia and ipsilateral third nerve pals

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: The PNS relays impulses in neurons away from the viscera.

options.label: B
options.text: The sympathetic nervous system has thoracolumbar outflow.

options.label: C
options.text: Erection is controlled by the parasympathetic nervous system.

options.label: D
options.text: Tearing is regulated by the parasympathetic nervous system.

questions.correct_answer: A. The PNS relays impulses in neurons away from the viscera.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Parasympathetic Nervous System

Sympathetic Nervous System

Outflow

Craniosacral outflow

Thoracolumbar outflow (Option B ruled out)

Preganglionic Neuron

Located in the midbrain, pons, medulla oblongata, and S2–S4 segments of the spinal cord

Located in the lateral horn of the spinal cord from Th 1–12 and L 1–2 segments

Preganglionic Fibers

Longer, myelinated

Shorter, myelinated

Relay of Impulses

Occurs in neurons close to viscera

Occurs in neurons a little away from the viscera they supply

Postganglionic Fibers

Short, nonmyelinated

Long, nonmyelinated

Neurotransmitter at Preganglionic Endings

Acetylcholine

Acetylcholine

Neurotransmitter at Postganglionic Endings

Acetylcholine

Adrenaline (except sweat glands, where acetylcholine is used)

Postganglionic Supply

Only viscera are supplied, do not supply blood vessels of skeletal muscles

All viscera are supplied; the exception is the suprarenal gland, which is supplied by preganglionic fibers

Heart rate

Decreased

Increased

Blood pressure

Mildly decreased

Increased

Urinary bladder

Voiding (decreased tone)

Increased sphincter tone

Bowel motility

Increased

Decreased motility

Lungs

Bronchoconstriction

Bronchodilation

Sweat glands

-

Sweating

Pupils

Constriction

Dilation

Sexual functions

Erection (Option C ruled out)

Ejaculation, orgasm

Lacrimal glands

Tearing (Option D ruled out)

-

questions.text: Where does the hypothalamospinal tract terminate before synapsing with the second-order neurons?

options.label: C
options.text: Intermediolateral cell column of the spinal cord

options.label: D
options.text: Posterior horn of the spinal cord

questions.correct_answer: C. Intermediolateral cell column of the spinal cord

questions.text: All of the following options are branches of the internal carotid artery except?
questions.explanation:
Branches

Areas supplied

Ophthalmic artery (Option A ruled out)

Contents of orbit

Posterior communicating artery (Option C ruled out)

Crus cerebri, optic tract, hypophysis and hypothalamus

Anterior choroidal artery (Option B ruled out)

Crus cerebri and choroid plexus of inferior horn of lateral ventricle

Anterior cerebral artery
  • Deep branches supply part of the internal capsule and the basal nuclei.
  • Cortical branches supply the medial surface of the hemisphere.

Middle cerebral artery
  • Deep or perforating branches supply the anterior limb of the internal capsule and part of the basal nuclei.
  • Cortical branches supply temporal, frontal and parietal lobe.

questions.text: A transverse section of the medulla oblongata at the level of the motor (pyramidal) decussation reveals modifications to the typical spinal cord structure. Which of the following changes is observed at this level?

options.label: A
options.text: Formation of the medial lemniscus from second-order axons

options.label: B
options.text: Crossing of corticospinal fibres from the anterior funiculi

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of the vestibular nuclei near the fourth ventricle

options.label: D
options.text: Appearance of the inferior olivary complex lateral to the pyramid

questions.correct_answer: B. Crossing of corticospinal fibres from the anterior funiculi
questions.explanation:
Level

Key Features

Motor Decussation Level

Corticospinal fibers crossing, ventral grey column divides, nucleus gracilis, spinocerebellar tracts.

Sensory Decussation Level

Nuclei gracilis and cuneatus, internal arcuate fibers forming the medial lemniscus, inferior olivary complex, spinocerebellar tracts, trigeminal nerve tracts.

Caudal End of Fourth Ventricle

Increased grey matter, cranial nerve nuclei (IX, X, XI, VIII), olivary complex, restiform body carrying afferent fibers.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct match of brainstem components with the respective cranial nerve nuclei that originate from them? Column A Column B a. Midbrain 1. Trigeminal nerve b. Pons 2. Oculomotor nerve c. Medulla oblongata 3. Glossopharyngeal nerve d. Pontomedullary junction 4. Facial nerve
questions.explanation:
Components of brainstem

Cranial nerves nuclei

Midbrain

Oculomotor (III) and trochlear (IV)

Pons

Trigeminal (V)

Medulla oblongata

Glossopharyngeal (IX), vagus (X), cranial accessory (XIcr) and hypoglossal (XII)

Pontomedullary junction

Abducens (VI), facial (VII) and vestibulocochlear (VIII)

questions.text: Which of the following findings is not a clinical manifestation of Wallenberg syndrome?

options.label: C
options.text: Ipsilateral facial pain and temperature loss

options.label: D
options.text: Contralateral body pain and temperature loss

questions.explanation:
Anatomical location

Presenting clinical feature

Nucleus ambiguous gives fibers to IX, X, and XI cranial nerves

Ipsilateral paralysis of muscles of the soft palate, pharynx, and larynx

Spinal nucleus and spinal tract of the trigeminal nerve

Ipsilateral facial pain and temperature loss (Option C ruled out)

Lateral spinothalamic tract

Contralateral body pain and temperature loss (Option D ruled out)

Vestibular nuclei

Vertigo

Inferior cerebellar peduncle, spino cerebellar tracts, and part of cerebellum

Ipsilateral ataxia (Option A)

Sympathetic fibres descend from the hypothalamus to cells in the lateral horn of spinal cord

Horner’s syndrome (Option B ruled out), comprising ptosis, enophthalmos, miosis, and anhydrosis

questions.text: Which of the following nerve palsy would suggest a lesion affecting the structures within the interpeduncular fossa?
Which among the following options is correctly matched for the alphabet labeled in the below image?
A 45-year-old patient presents with a severe infection of the face. Which of the following venous structures could allow the infection to spread to the cavernous sinus?

A 45-year-old patient presents with symptoms of headache and visual disturbances. Imaging studies reveal a large clot in the superior sagittal sinus. Which of the following statements about the superior sagittal sinus is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It drains directly into the internal jugular vein.

options.label: B
options.text: It runs along the midline, attached to the falx cerebri, and drains into the confluence of sinuses.

options.label: C
options.text: It is located in the falx cerebelli and connects with the occipital sinus.

options.label: D
options.text: It receives blood from the diploic veins within the cranial bones.

questions.correct_answer: B. It runs along the midline, attached to the falx cerebri, and drains into the confluence of sinuses.
questions.explanation:
Sinus

Location

Drainage

Superior sagittal sinus (Option B)

Along midline, attached to falx cerebri (Option C ruled out)

Confluence of sinuses, usually right side (Option A ruled out)

Inferior sagittal sinus

Lower edge of falx cerebri

Continues as straight sinus

Straight sinus

Junction of falx cerebri and tentorium cerebelli

Drains into left transverse sinus

Transverse sinuses

Along tentorium cerebelli

Continue as sigmoid sinuses

Sigmoid sinuses

From transverse sinuses

Becomes internal jugular vein

Occipital sinus

In falx cerebelli

Drains into confluence of sinuses

Cavernous sinuses

Plexiform, on either side of sphenoid bone

Receives blood from ophthalmic veins, drains via superior and inferior petrosal sinuses

Intercavernous sinuses

Connects the two cavernous sinuses

-

Superior petrosal sinuses

Drains cavernous sinus into transverse sinus

-

Inferior petrosal sinuses

Drains cavernous sinus into internal jugular vein

-

Sphenoparietal sinuses

Under lesser wings of sphenoid bone

Drains into cavernous sinus

Basilar sinus and plexus

Over clivus, connects cavernous and petrosal sinuses

-

Marginal sinus

Encircles foramen magnum

Connects with basilar plexus and occipital sinus

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient presents with difficulty speaking, swallowing, and hoarseness of voice. On examination, there is noticeable wasting of one side of the tongue and weakness in the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. The patient also exhibits contralateral hemiplegia and contralateral loss of sensation. Which of the following lesions is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Description

Common Symptoms

Dysarthria, dysphagia, dysphonia, tongue wasting, muscle weakness/wasting.

Additional Symptoms

Contralateral hemiplegia, contralateral hemianesthesia, cerebellar signs, nystagmus, internuclear ophthalmoplegia.

Causes

Space-occupying tumours (e.g., meningiomas), gliomas, demyelination, stroke.

Illustrative Case

Brown-Séquard syndrome shows the effect of lesion location on neurological deficits.

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes the corticonuclear tract?

options.label: A
options.text: It terminates exclusively in the spinal cord with an ipsilateral projection.

options.label: B
options.text: It descends through the internal capsule and pons, terminating on cranial nerve nuclei with a contralateral projection.

options.label: C
options.text: It controls involuntary movements of the head and neck muscles.

options.label: D
options.text: The term "corticobulbar" is more accurate than "corticonuclear" for describing its function.

questions.correct_answer: B. It descends through the internal capsule and pons, terminating on cranial nerve nuclei with a contralateral projection.

questions.text: At the level of the facial colliculus, the fibres of which cranial nerves form a loop around the abducens nucleus, creating the colliculus?
questions.explanation:
Section

Dorsal Aspect

Ventral Aspect

Facial Colliculus Level

Medial longitudinal fasciculus: beneath fourth ventricle, lateral to median sulcus

Medial lemniscus: ovoid bundle in ventral pontine tegmentum
 

Abducens nucleus: sends fibres ventro-laterally and caudally

Trapezoid body fibers and nuclei cross midline along medial lemniscus
 

Facial nerve nucleus: ventral, lateral, caudal to abducens nucleus

Central tegmental tract: longitudinally through mid-pontine tegmentum
 

Facial nerve fibres curve dorsally and laterally over abducens nucleus (facial colliculus) (Option C)

Pontine nuclei: transverse pontocerebellar fibres form contralateral middle cerebellar peduncle
 

Inferior cerebellar peduncle (restiform and juxtarestiform bodies): superolateral to vestibular nuclei

Descending fibres (frontopontine, corticospinal, parieto-temporo-occipito-pontine): longitudinally through basal pons

Trigeminal Nerve Nuclei Level

Superior cerebellar peduncle: lateral wall of fourth ventricle

Medial and lateral lemnisci: convex lemniscal arch, separating tegmentum from basal pons
 

Superior medullary velum: roof of fourth ventricle

Trapezoid body fibres and nuclei: curve across midline in ventral tegmentum
 

Superior fovea: lateral margin of fourth ventricle, overlies trigeminal nerve nuclei

  
 

Mesencephalic tract of trigeminal nerve: dorsolateral tegmentum

  

Section Level

Key Structures

Facial colliculus (lower pons)
  • Fourth ventricle above stria medullaris
  • Facial nerve fibres form the facial colliculus

Dorsal aspect (lower pons)
  • Medial longitudinal fasciculus
  • Abducens and facial nerve nuclei
  • Inferior cerebellar peduncle

Ventral aspect (lower pons)
  • Medial lemniscus
  • Trapezoid body and nuclei
  • Pontine nuclei and pontocerebellar fibres

Trigeminal nerve nuclei (mid pons)
  • Superior cerebellar peduncle
  • Motor and sensory nuclei of the trigeminal nerve
  • Mesencephalic tract

Ventral aspect (mid pons)
  • Lemniscal arch (medial and lateral lemnisci)
  • Trapezoid body fibres and nuclei

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with lesions at the level marked in the midbrain?
Which of the following statements is not correct regarding lemniscus?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a collection of axons running in the spinal cord

options.label: B
options.text: The lateral lemniscus is a part of the auditory pathway

options.label: C
options.text: Spinal leminiscus is affected in wallenberg syndrome

options.label: D
options.text: Spinal lemniscus carries pain and temperature sensation

questions.correct_answer: A. It is a collection of axons running in the spinal cord

questions.text: A 55-year-old man diagnosed with B12 deficiency presents with difficulty maintaining balance. On examination, he shows a loss of vibration and fine touch sensation in his lower limbs, while pain and temperature sensations are intact. Which of the following pathways is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Column

Descending tracts

Ascending tracts

Anterior white column

Anterior corticospinal, vestibulospinal, tectospinal, medial reticulospinal

Anterior spinothalamic

Lateral white column

Lateral corticospinal, rubrospinal, lateral reticulospinal, hypothalamospinal

Lateral spinothalamic, anterior spinocerebellar, posterior spinocerebellar, spinotectal

Posterior white column(Dorsal column)

  

• Fasciculus gracilis (tract of Goll)

• Fasciculus cuneatus (tract of Burdach)

Category

Details

Components
  • Fasciculus Gracilis: Carries sensory information from the lower limbs (Option C)
  • Fasciculus Cuneatus: Carries sensory information from the upper limbs

Sensations
  • Pressure
  • Tactile discrimination
  • Vibration
  • Conscious Proprioception
  • Stereognosis

Neuronal Pathway
  • 1st Order Neuron: Located in the dorsal root ganglion
  • 2nd Order Neuron: Located in the medulla oblongata
  • 3rd Order Neuron: Located in the thalamus

Category

Details

Types (Options A & B ruled out)
  • Lateral Spinothalamic Tract: Carries pain and temperature sensations
  • Ventral Spinothalamic Tract: Carries crude touch and pressure sensations

Pathway
  • 1st Order Neuron: Located in the dorsal root ganglion
  • 2nd Order Neuron: Located in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord
  • 3rd Order Neuron: Located in the thalamus

Category

Details

Types
  • Lateral Corticospinal Tract: Contains about 90% of the corticospinal fibers
  • Ventral Corticospinal Tract: Contains the remaining fibers

Function
  • Controls fine and skilled voluntary motor activities, such as threading a needle
  • Works in conjunction with the corticobulbar (corticonuclear) tracts

Neuronal Pathway

Receives axons from the cerebrum (upper motor neuron, UMN type of fibers)

Effects of Damage
  • Damage to Pyramidal System: Causes spastic paralysis of skeletal muscles below the level of the lesion
  • Damage to Lower Motor Neurons: Causes flaccid paralysis at the level of the lesion

questions.text: Which of the following arteries is primarily responsible for supplying the sublenticular part of the internal capsule, which carries auditory fibres?

options.label: A
options.text: Recurrent branch of anterior cerebral artery

options.label: B
options.text: Direct branches from the internal carotid

questions.text: A 62-year-old presents with sudden-onset left-sided weakness, primarily affecting the arm and face. On examination, he has difficulty with speech, displaying both expressive and receptive aphasia. He also shows left-sided facial drooping and an inability to move his left upper limb effectively. Sensation is relatively intact in his lower limb. Which artery is most likely affected?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Artery Affected Areas Involved Clinical Manifestations
  • ↳ Artery Affected

  • ↳ Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA) (Option A) Medial surface of the frontal and parietal lobes, corpus callosum Contralateral weakness and sensory loss (lower limb > upper limb) Urinary incontinence, Personality changes (frontal lobe involvement), Transcortical motor aphasia (dominant hemisphere)
  • ↳ Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA) (Option A)
  • ↳ Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA)
  • ↳ Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA)

  • ↳ (Option A)

  • ↳ Medial surface of the frontal and parietal lobes, corpus callosum

  • ↳ Contralateral weakness and sensory loss (lower limb > upper limb) Urinary incontinence, Personality changes (frontal lobe involvement), Transcortical motor aphasia (dominant hemisphere)
  • ↳ Contralateral weakness and sensory loss (lower limb > upper limb)
  • ↳ Contralateral weakness and sensory loss (lower limb > upper limb)
  • ↳ Urinary incontinence,

  • ↳ Personality changes (frontal lobe involvement),
  • ↳ Personality changes
  • ↳ Transcortical motor aphasia (dominant hemisphere)
  • ↳ Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) (Option C) Lateral surface of the frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes, basal ganglia, internal capsule Contralateral weakness and sensory loss (face and upper limb > lower limb) Aphasia (dominant hemisphere), Hemineglect (non-dominant hemisphere), Homonymous hemianopia Gaze preference towards the side of the lesion
  • ↳ Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) (Option C)
  • ↳ Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)
  • ↳ Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)
  • ↳ (Option C)
  • ↳ (Option C)
  • ↳ Lateral surface of the frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes, basal ganglia, internal capsule
  • ↳ Lateral surface of the frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes, basal ganglia, internal capsule
  • ↳ Contralateral weakness and sensory loss (face and upper limb > lower limb) Aphasia (dominant hemisphere), Hemineglect (non-dominant hemisphere), Homonymous hemianopia Gaze preference towards the side of the lesion
  • ↳ Contralateral weakness and sensory loss (face and upper limb > lower limb) Aphasia (dominant hemisphere), Hemineglect (non-dominant hemisphere), Homonymous hemianopia Gaze preference towards the side of the lesion
  • ↳ Contralateral weakness and sensory loss (face and upper limb > lower limb)
  • ↳ Contralateral weakness and sensory loss (face and upper limb > lower limb)
  • ↳ Aphasia (dominant hemisphere),
  • ↳ Aphasia
  • ↳ Hemineglect (non-dominant hemisphere),
  • ↳ Homonymous hemianopia
  • ↳ Gaze preference towards the side of the lesion
  • ↳ Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA) (Option B) Occipital lobe, inferior part of temporal lobe, thalamus Contralateral homonymous hemianopia , Visual agnosia , Thalamic pain syndrome, Cortical blindness (if bilateral), Memory deficits (if temporal lobe is involved)
  • ↳ Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA) (Option B)
  • ↳ Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA)
  • ↳ Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA)
  • ↳ (Option B)
  • ↳ (Option B)
  • ↳ Occipital lobe, inferior part of temporal lobe, thalamus
  • ↳ Occipital lobe, inferior part of temporal lobe, thalamus
  • ↳ Contralateral homonymous hemianopia , Visual agnosia , Thalamic pain syndrome, Cortical blindness (if bilateral), Memory deficits (if temporal lobe is involved)
  • ↳ Contralateral homonymous hemianopia , Visual agnosia , Thalamic pain syndrome, Cortical blindness (if bilateral), Memory deficits (if temporal lobe is involved)
  • ↳ Contralateral homonymous hemianopia ,
  • ↳ Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
  • ↳ Visual agnosia ,
  • ↳ Visual agnosia
  • ↳ Thalamic pain syndrome,
  • ↳ Cortical blindness (if bilateral),
  • ↳ Cortical blindness
  • ↳ Memory deficits (if temporal lobe is involved)

Artery Affected

Areas Involved

Clinical Manifestations

Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA)

(Option A)

Medial surface of the frontal and parietal lobes, corpus callosum
  • Contralateral weakness and sensory loss (lower limb > upper limb)
  • Urinary incontinence,
  • Personality changes (frontal lobe involvement),
  • Transcortical motor aphasia (dominant hemisphere)

Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)

(Option C)

Lateral surface of the frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes, basal ganglia, internal capsule
  • Contralateral weakness and sensory loss (face and upper limb > lower limb)
  • Aphasia (dominant hemisphere),
  • Hemineglect (non-dominant hemisphere),
  • Homonymous hemianopia
  • Gaze preference towards the side of the lesion

Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA)

(Option B)

Occipital lobe, inferior part of temporal lobe, thalamus
  • Contralateral homonymous hemianopia,
  • Visual agnosia,
  • Thalamic pain syndrome,
  • Cortical blindness (if bilateral),
  • Memory deficits (if temporal lobe is involved)

questions.text: Identify the artery highlighted in blue in the following image.

A 45-year-old patient presents with Horner’s syndrome, but notably, the patient does not exhibit anhidrosis. Based on the absence of anhidrosis, which of the following is the most likely location of the lesion?

Which of the following statements about prevertebral/paravertebral ganglia is/are true? Prevertebral ganglia are also known as collateral ganglia. Prevertebral ganglia are a part of the parasympathetic nervous system. Paravertebral ganglia supply the abdominal viscera. The celiac ganglion is a paravertebral ganglion.
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Prevertebral Ganglia

Paravertebral Ganglia

Alternate Names

Also known as collateral ganglia or preaortic ganglia. (Statement I)

Also known as sympathetic chain ganglia.

Sympathetic Pathway

Both are part of the sympathetic nervous system.

(Statement II ruled out)

Location

Anterior to the aorta, close to major arteries like the celiac, superior mesenteric, and inferior mesenteric arteries.

Adjacent to the vertebral column, forming sympathetic chains on either side of the spine.

Structure

Associated with the abdominal aorta and related to major arteries.

Forms a chain along the spine, with ganglia in the cervical, thoracic, lumbar, sacral, and coccygeal regions.

Function

Supplies abdominal and pelvic organs, controls visceral functions like peristalsis and secretion.

(Statement III ruled out)

Supplies the thoracic viscera, blood vessels, skin, sweat glands, and arrector pili muscles.

Preganglionic Fibers

Receive preganglionic fibers from the splanchnic nerves (e.g., greater, lesser, least splanchnic).

Receive preganglionic fibers from the spinal cord segments (T1-L2) via white rami communicantes.

Postganglionic Fibers

Postganglionic fibers form plexuses like the celiac and hypogastric plexus, supplying abdominal and pelvic organs.

Postganglionic fibers distributed via grey rami communicantes to spinal nerves and target skin, blood vessels, and thoracic viscera.

Notable Ganglia

Includes the celiac, superior mesenteric, inferior mesenteric, and aorticorenal ganglia.

(Statement IV ruled out)

Includes cervical, thoracic, lumbar, sacral ganglia, and ganglion impar.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Preganglionic fibers in both the sympathetic and parasympathetic systems are myelinated.

options.label: B
options.text: Postganglionic fibers in both the sympathetic and parasympathetic systems are unmyelinated

options.label: C
options.text: Most sweat glands are sympathetic and adrenergic.

options.label: D
options.text: Acetylcholine is a neurotransmitter found in sympathetic ganglia.

questions.correct_answer: C. Most sweat glands are sympathetic and adrenergic.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents with progressive weakness in her left leg. On examination, you observe that her left leg has decreased muscle tone, and shows significant muscle atrophy. Given these findings, which of the following additional signs is likely to be present?
questions.explanation:
Feature

LMN Paralysis

UMN Paralysis

Muscle Tone

Decreased

Increased

 

Type of Paralysis

 

Flaccid

Spastic (Option C ruled out)

Muscle Atrophy

Occurs later

No atrophy

Reaction of Degeneration

Seen

Not seen

 

Tendon Reflexes

 

Absent

Exaggerated (Option A ruled out)

Side of Affected Body

Ipsilateral

Contralateral

Babinski Sign

Negative

Positive (Option B ruled out)

Fasciculation

Present

Absent

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents following a fall from a ladder. The patient exhibits specific neurological symptoms: loss of pain and temperature sensation in the left leg, difficulty identifying the position of the right leg with eyes closed, and complete loss of sensation at the T12 level of the trunk on the right. Which of the following statements is false for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Loss of proprioception in the right leg occurs due right dorsal column.

options.label: B
options.text: Loss of pain in the left leg occurs due to the left spinothalamic tract.

options.label: C
options.text: Damage to the ventral nerve roots at the T12 level results in loss of sensation.

options.label: D
options.text: Spastic paralysis of the right leg

questions.correct_answer: B. Loss of pain in the left leg occurs due to the left spinothalamic tract.
